title.narrative: World Bank ASTAE Multi Donor Trust Fund 2011-2014

description.narrative: Stöd till Världsbankens regionala givargemensamma fond "Asia Sustainable and Alternative Energy Program (ASTAE)" med 40 million SEK mellan åren 2012-2015. TF stödjer alternativa energikällor och effektiv energianvändning i Världsbankens utlåning. Det övergripande målet med programmet är att öka tillgången på modern energi för människor i fattigdom samt att skydda miljön.

World Bank Multi donor TF to scale up the use of sustainable energy solutionsin Asia. Promotion of three pillars: Renewable Energy, Energy Efficiency and Access to Energy, through:Innovative delivery mechanisms, Enhance policy abd regulatory frameworks, Capacity building and share knowledge, Introduce new technologies or mainstream proven tech., Mitigation and adaptation to climate change

participating-org.narrative: IBRD/International Bank for Reconstruction and Development/The World Bank

sector.narrative: Energy generation, renewable sources - multiple technologies

tag.narrative: 5.b - Enhance the use of enabling technology, in particular information and communications technology, to promote the empowerment of women.
5.b - Öka användningen av gynnsam teknik, i synnerhet informations- och kommunikationsteknik, för att främja kvinnors egenmakt
7.1 - By 2030, ensure universal access to affordable, reliable and modern energy services.
7.1 - Senast 2030 säkerställa allmän tillgång till ekonomiskt överkomliga, tillförlitliga och moderna energitjänster.

7.b - By 2030, expand infrastructure and upgrade technology for supplying modern and sustainable energy services for all in developing countries, in particular least developed countries, small island developing States and landlocked developing countries, in accordance with their respective programmes of support.

7.b - Till 2030 bygga ut infrastrukturen och uppgradera tekniken för att leverera moderna och hållbara energitjänster till alla i utvecklingsländerna, i synnerhet de minst utvecklade länderna och små önationer under utveckling.

description.narrative: The Asia Sustainable and alternative Energy Program (ASTAE) is a multidonor trust fund administered by the World Bank and, since July 2014, by the World Bank Energy Sector Management Assistance Program (ESMAP). Since 1992, ASTAE has been helping to scale up the use of sustainable energy in the Asia-Pacific region to reduce energy poverty and protect the environment. ASTAE has achieved its objectives set by its three consecutive Business Plans. The First Phase (1992-2009) aimed to mainstream alternative energy into the World Bank's lending and grants in the East Asia and Pacific Region. The Second Phase (2009-2011) sought to scale up ASTAE's activities, mainly within individual countries. The Third Phase (2012-2017) aimed to promote low-carbon, green growth and to increase the supply of and access to sustainable energy on a regional basis. Sida has supported the implementation of all three ASTAE business plans (BP). This closing memo concerns the support to the third BP 2012-2017 and its three pillars: Renewable Energy, Energy Efficiency and Energy Access. The third BP was supported by Sweden the Netherlands, UK and the WB Group. Examples of results: In Vietnam, the ASTAE-funded activity provided support to the Ministry of Industry and Trade, the Electricity Regulatory Authority of Vietnam, and other relevant stakeholders for the development of a renewable energy regulatory infrastructure. Among results are, the Renewable Energy Development Strategy was approved, the Technical Standards for Small Hydro were adopted, Environmental and Social Guidelines for Small Hydro were approved, the National Renewable Energy Database was prepared, and more than 300 Standardized Power Purchase Agreements were signed for grid-connected renewable. In Tuvalu, ASTAE informed the preparation of the Tuvalu Energy Sector Development Project, which aims to help the government prioritize the most efficient energy investments. Within the Bangladesh Rural Electrification and Renewable Energy Development II Project, funding from ASTAE helped design a gender-responsive household fuel component for the program and supported a Technical Standards Committee to select the right models of improved cook stoves. The project supported research and development in the traditional stove market to move to safer, more efficient stoves, promoted research and development of an indigenous higher efficiency stove, and provided supervision of the implementation of the dissemination of cook stoves. In Mongolia, ASTAE contributed to raising the awareness of the impact and benefits of the Solar Ger (Yurt) Electrification Program. The improved understanding—and therefore acceptance by the beneficiaries - of internationally proven practice in electrification that fit the unique circumstances in Mongolia resulted in more than 54,000 herder families gaining access to energy through solar home systems. Over the course of the third BP (2012-2017), ASTAE funded 66 activities for a total of $22.1 million that directly contributed to World Bank projects totalling $9.6 billion. Overall, between 2012 and 2017, every donor provided dollar leveraged about $436 in World Bank sustainable energy lending and grants. An un-expected but impressive result. The unspent funds that were returned to Sida is 6,170 SEK.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
